Date:  Fri, 06 Jan 2017 11:14:37 +0000
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  Morning comets...
Good morning.
Between some other comets, I allow myself to put you the brightest of this morning ...
C 2015 V2 Johnson (Coma: +/- 2'40, Tail: +/- 13 ')
http://6888comete.free.fr/en/imageC2015V2Johnsonfrance.htm
C 2015 ER61 Panstarrs and NGC5897, mosaic 2x(6x60s).
Lots of gradient due to low cloud passages and the rising sun.
http://6888comete.free.fr/en/imageC2015ER61Panstarrsfrance.htm
C 2016 U1 Neowise (Coma: +/- 2'30, Tail: +/- 20 ')
Low clouds during iterations.
http://6888comete.free.fr/en/imageC2016U1Neowisefrance.htm
Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François
C10/W96/A77

To: Comet Images
Sent: Friday, 6 January 2017, 11:14
Subject: [Comet-Images] Morning comets...

  Good morning.
Between some other comets, I allow myself to put you the brightest of this morning ...
C 2015 V2 Johnson (Coma: +/- 2'40, Tail: +/- 13 ')
http://6888comete.free.fr/en/imageC2015V2Johnsonfrance.htm
C 2015 ER61 Panstarrs and NGC5897, mosaic 2x(6x60s).
Lots of gradient due to low cloud passages and the rising sun.
http://6888comete.free.fr/en/imageC2015ER61Panstarrsfrance.htm
C 2016 U1 Neowise (Coma: +/- 2'30, Tail: +/- 20 ')
Low clouds during iterations.
http://6888comete.free.fr/en/imageC2016U1Neowisefrance.htm
Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François

{font-family:Verdana;font-size:10px;font-weight:normal;}#yiv8235043786 .yiv8235043786green {color:#628c2a;}#yiv8235043786 .yiv8235043786MsoNormal {margin:0 0 0 0;}#yiv8235043786 o {font-size:0;}#yiv8235043786 #yiv8235043786photos div {float:left;width:72px;}#yiv8235043786 #yiv8235043786photos div div {border:1px solid Date:  Fri, 13 Jan 2017 06:48:47 +1100
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 45P in STEREO sat..
Gidday Michael,

Some tail dynamics can be see across the sequence, so wide field image
above 3-5 degrees can be correlated to events in the stereo FOV.
Might be hard to get from the ground....

regards, Alan.

Date:  Thu, 19 Jan 2017 15:25:55 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2016 U1 (NEOWISE)  @ Jan.5,2017
Object/Date:
Comet C/2016 U1 (NEOWISE) @ Jan.5,2017

Description:
Comet C/2016 U1 (NEOWISE) imaged in the dawn of January 5th 2017, to a few days of be unobservable because its approach to Sun. In this image the comet shines in magnitude 8 and throw a ionic tail of half degree long. Could be one of the latest images of comet, besides of the probabilities of desintegration, wont be observable from Earth because remain in conjuction with Sun until April, then will be too faint.
Tech data:
GSO 8" f/3.8 & Canon EOS-100D (3 x 120 sec. at ISO-800, cropped) from Llosa de Ranes, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2016u1-neowise-170105/

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Thu, 19 Jan 2017 15:35:45 +0000

  Object/Date:Comet C/2016 U1 (NEOWISE)  @ Jan.5,2017
Description:Comet C/2016 U1 (NEOWISE) imaged in the dawn of January 5th 2017, to a few days of be unobservable because its approach to Sun. In this image the comet shines in magnitude 8 and throw a ionic tail of half degree long. Could be one of the latest images of comet, besides of the probabilities of desintegration, wont be observable from Earth because remain in conjuction with Sun until April, then will be too faint.Tech data:GSO 8" f/3.8 & Canon EOS-100D (3 x 120 sec. at ISO-800, cropped) from Llosa de Ranes, Valencia (Spain)

Date:  Sat, 21 Jan 2017 02:19:06 +0000
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Comet 2P Encke dust trail
Hello all,
I imaged 2p Encke earlier this evening (at Tarbatness observatory MPC Code I81) and processing of 12x120s exposures using C14 and SBIG ST9XE shows the comet well developed  with a fan shaped coma and a dust trail before and after the comet.My image can be seen here:Comet 2P Encke | British Astronomical Association

|
| | |

|

|
|
| |
Comet 2P Encke | British Astronomical Association
| |

|

| 

Date:  Sat, 21 Jan 2017 16:24:05 +0100
From:  Alfons Diepvens 
Subject:  C23 -NEW images 18-19-20 Jan 2017


NEW images 18-19-20 Jan. 2017

2P Encke - 19 Jan
2P Encke - 20 Jan
2P Encke - false color
2P Encke - Neg*** faint tail

30P Reinmuth
41P Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak
56P Slaughter-Burnham
74P Smirnova-Chernykh
93P Lovas
117P Helin-Roman-Alu
128P Shoemaker-Holt
143P Kowal-Mrkos
315P LONEOS
226P Pigott-LINEAR-Kowalski
P2015 TP200 LINEAR

C2010 U3 Boattini
C2013 US10 Catalina
C2014 A4 SONEAR
C2015 V1 PANSTARRS
C2015 V2 Johnson
C2015 V2 Johnson - false color
C2015 VL62 Lemmon-Yeung-PANSTARRS
C2015 XY1 Lemmon
C2016 A1 PANSTARRS
C2016 T3 PANSTARRS

with a direct link to the image:
http://www.astronomie.be/alfons.diepvens/cometimages/index.html

Alfons Diepvens 
Date:  Sat, 21 Jan 2017 16:56:48 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova  @ Jan.5,2017
Object/Date:
Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ Jan.5,2017

Description:
Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova imaged at Twelfth Night. After overcome perihelion the comet 45P is moving toward Earth keeping its brightness and its long ionic tail with more than 1.5 degrees long faint but visible in this image getting out of field, in spite of at moment of taking the comet was at only 7 degrees altitude on the horizon, in astronomical twilight and with crescent moon high in the sky.
Tech data:
GSO 8" f/3.8 & Canon EOS-100D (7 x 120 sec. at ISO-800) from Benali, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/45p-honda-mrkos-pajdusakova-20170105/

Clear and Dark Skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo

Thanks for sharing !!!

congratulations on this increasingly sustained follow-up images of the comets . Beleave me, I know this takes a lot of work and especially sustain this !
This is highly appreciated !

keep up the great work !

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck

Date:  Sun, 22 Jan 2017 03:53:43 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C23 -NEW images 18-19-20 Jan 2017
Alfons,

I belive the "tail" you mark in Enckes shot is the orbital plane debris. It might be worth noting that using this tool:

https://in-the-sky.org/solarsystem.php

Earth moves into the orbital plane of the comet in late feb or early march. What do you think?

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Wed, 25 Jan 2017 17:13:40 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Comet 2P/Encke @ January 23,2017
Object/Date:
Comet 2P/Encke @ January 23,2017

Description:
The periodic comet 2P/Encke imaged in January 23, 2017 returns to inner Solar System in present apparition with perihelion in next March. The comet has already fired its gassy emission making a coma that reach some 6' of angular diameter in this image (350.000 Km in absolute terms) and with an intense green color wich point to a strong emission of diatomic carbon. The tail will belate a pair of weeks in begin its development, when the comet will start to be observable with binoculars.

Tech data:
Planewave 20" CDK 2280mm f/4.5 & FLI-PL11002M (L:4×120s Bin1+ RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Mayhill, New Mexico

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2p-encke-20170123/

Clear and Dark Skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Wed, 25 Jan 2017 18:13:28 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 2P/Encke @ January 23,2017
The green (cyan actually) color is very encouraging for such a far away object!

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

#yiv4021359467

Object/Date:
Comet 2P/Encke @ January 23,2017

Description:
The periodic comet 2P/Encke imaged in January 23, 2017
returns to inner Solar System in present apparition with
perihelion in next March. The comet has already fired its
gassy emission making a coma that reach some 6'  of
angular diameter in this image
(350.000 Km in absolute terms) and with an intense green
color wich point to a strong emission of diatomic carbon.
The tail will belate a pair of weeks in begin its
development, when the comet will start to be observable with
binoculars.

Tech data:
Planewave 20" CDK 2280mm f/4.5 & FLI-PL11002M
(L:4×120s Bin1+ RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Mayhill, New
Mexico

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2p-encke-20170123/

Clear and Dark Skies.

José J.
Chambó
(Valencia,
Spain)

cometografia.es

Date:  Fri, 27 Jan 2017 21:43:24 +0000
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Comet 2p Encke dust trail?
Hello all,I recently posted an image I had taken of 2P on 20170120 at this link:
Comet 2P Encke | British Astronomical Association

|
| | |

|

|
|
| |
Comet 2P Encke | British Astronomical Association
| |

|

|

This appeared to show a tail and a dust trail .
Iganocio Ferrin wrote to me asked the following question:Hello Denis:
I did like you image of 2P very much.  The trail is very visible.However I have a question.  The JPL ephemeris indicatesthat the comet was 8 degrees above the ecliptic plane.Thus Earth was not at the comet's orbital plane.  How thenit was possible to register a trail?

I have now imaged the comet again (it is low atltude in twilight here at 57N latitude) last night. The same features show again in my image at this link;Comet 2P Encke | British Astronomical Association

|
| | |

|

|
|
| |
Comet 2P Encke | British Astronomical Association
| |

|

|

So I ask the lists two questions. Has any other observer recorded these tail/dust trail features? Can someone answer Ignacio's question about the orbital plane?Best wishesDenis BuczynskiBritish Astronomical AssociationComet Section

Date:  Sat, 28 Jan 2017 09:51:28 +1100
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 2p Encke dust trail?
The dust tail is detectable in Stereo HI1A imager. The 1024x1024 imager is
aligned to have the ecliptic along the horizontal center line. The Fov is
20 x 20 degrees and sees more to infrared end of the spectrum.
At my blog here,

http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Ty6JJUnlPYQ/UoV5E7AgHBI/AAAAAAAAAtc/NGm1kMt6uuc/s1600/2013-encke-hi1a-3.gif

The dust radials are seem when comet is between 5-10 degrees above ecliptic.
So, I think they are detectable farther away from the ecliptic line, if
using red sensitive imagers.

Kind regards, Alan Watson.

Date:  Sat, 28 Jan 2017 09:33:26 +0000
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] Re: [BAA Comets] Comet 2p Encke dust trail?
Good morning.
The dust trail is very thin ... and as the comet descends towards the western horizon, it becomes very complicated to be able to observe it.Despite this, please find two images of this comet, one can see there oblique look the dust trail.Hopefully this will help.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image2PEnckefrance.htm
Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-FrançoisC10/France

De : "'Richard Miles' rmiles.btee@btinternet.com [comets-ml]"
À : BAA Comets discussion list ; Yahoogroups ; Comet Images
Envoyé le : Samedi 28 janvier 2017 0h05
Objet : [comets-ml] Re: [BAA Comets] Comet 2p Encke dust trail?

  Hi Denis,

My understanding is that, according to JPL Horizons, we pass through the
plane of its orbit on February 22 and at the time of your Jan 20 observation
the angle was about 4.7 degrees off of the orbital plane of 2P/Encke. So, as
the days wear on, any such dust trail should become increasingly obvious.
Perihelion is on March 10 so this could be a particularly interesting
apparition.

Hope this helps,
Richard Miles

De : "'Michael S. P. Kelley' msk@astro.umd.edu [comets-ml]"
À : comets-ml@yahoogroups.com
Cc : BAA Comets discussion list ; Comet Images
Envoyé le : Samedi 28 janvier 2017 18h43
Objet : Re: [comets-ml] Re: [BAA Comets] Comet 2p Encke dust trail?

  Hi everyone,
Great images!  Dust trails do not require low orbital plane angles to be visible.  In fact, it is much easier to demonstrate that the observed feature is a dust trail when the angle is greater than 0 degrees.  At low orbital plane angles most dust, whether in the trail or not, is enhanced and found near the projected orbit vector.  A good example is our image of comet 48P/Johnson from the Spitzer Space Telescope:
http://www.astro.umd.edu/~msk/science/trails/johnson.png

It even has a similar morphology as the Encke images above.  The orbital plane angle was 8 degrees at the time of our observation.  Compare that to our image of 129P/S-L 3, with an orbital plane angle of ~1 deg:
http://www.astro.umd.edu/~msk/science/trails/sl3.png

Cheers,Mike Kelley #yiv5540118144 #yiv5540118144 -- #yiv5540118144ygrp-mkp {border:1px solid #d8d8d8;font-family:Arial;margin:10px 0;padding:0 10px;}#yiv5540118144 #yiv5540118144ygrp-mkp hr Date:  Wed, 01 Feb 2017 03:46:49 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Johnson V2 - A very deep exposure
Hello All,

The sky has finally cleared for the first time in 2017 here in Arizona, and the 12.5" with new mirror coatings was put to good use once again on imaging faint comets. This is a combination of 35 Lum channels at 3m each, and six color frames also 3 mins, totalling 2 hours. I will be posting another image in a day or two with the background stationary to show the hordes of galaxies that was in this remarkable field! For now, I used the color data to properly hue the comet and star field and you can see that this comet is allready a very nice photographic object.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/JohnsonV2-013017.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Wed, 01 Feb 2017 06:39:51 +0100
From:  rolando ligustri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Johnson V2 - A very deep exposure
very beautiful!

regards
Rolando

-----Messaggio originale-----
From: Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]
Sent: Wednesday, February 01, 2017 4:46 AM
To: Comet Group
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Johnson V2 - A very deep exposure

Hello All,

The sky has finally cleared for the first time in 2017 here in Arizona, and the 12.5" with
new mirror coatings was put to good use once again on imaging faint comets. This is a
combination of 35 Lum channels at 3m each, and six color frames also 3 mins, totalling 2
hours. I will be posting another image in a day or two with the background stationary to
show the hordes of galaxies that was in this remarkable field! For now, I used the color
data to properly hue the comet and star field and you can see that this comet is allready
a very nice photographic object.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/JohnsonV2-013017.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

------------------------------------
Posted by: Chris Schur

Date:  Wed, 01 Feb 2017 17:56:36 +0000
From:  Adriano 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Johnson V2 - A very deep exposure
Thanks Rolando.

Regards/Mandi

Adriano Valvasori

________________________________
Da: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com per conto di 'rolando ligustri' rolando.ligustri@alice.it [Comet-Images]
Inviato: mercoledì 1 febbraio 2017 06.39
A: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Oggetto: Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Johnson V2 - A very deep exposure

very beautiful!

regards

-----Messaggio originale-----
From: Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]
Sent: Wednesday, February 01, 2017 4:46 AM
To: Comet Group
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Johnson V2 - A very deep exposure

Hello All,

The sky has finally cleared for the first time in 2017 here in Arizona, and the 12.5" with
new mirror coatings was put to good use once again on imaging faint comets. This is a
combination of 35 Lum channels at 3m each, and six color frames also 3 mins, totalling 2
hours. I will be posting another image in a day or two with the background stationary to
show the hordes of galaxies that was in this remarkable field! For now, I used the color
data to properly hue the comet and star field and you can see that this comet is allready
a very nice photographic object.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/JohnsonV2-013017.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

------------------------------------
Posted by: Chris Schur
------------------------------------

------------------------------------

Yahoo Groups Links

---

https://www.avast.com/antivirus 

Date:  Thu, 02 Feb 2017 03:36:58 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Johnson V2 - January 30 with hordes of galaxies
Greetings, this is the stationary comet against the starry background with galaxies ranging from magnitude 16 - 22. This comet is going to be very nice!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/JohnsonV2-013017-1.html

Clear Skies

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Sat, 11 Feb 2017 10:20:10 +0000
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  73P and 73Pa 2017 02 11 Chile
Good morning.

T400RC Remote, SpaceObs., A.Maury, Chile :

Fragmentation of the comet 73P S-W (discovery made by Thierry Noël), without filter, 40, 30 and 20x30s, sampling of 1.55"/pixel.

Coma 0073P : +/-26", Tail : +/-40" long, structure direction the tail of PA : +/-285°,
m2 : 15.0N (+/-0.4), aperture radius for measures : 6.2"

Coma 0073Pa : +/-1.10', Tail and Structure direction the tail of PA : stellar aspect,
m2 : 13.2N (+/-0.3) aperture radius for measures : 6.2"
m1 : 12.6T aperture radius for measures : 0.33'

Separation between the two cometary nuclei : +/- 40"

Astrometry :

COD W96
OBS A. Maury, J.-B. de Vanssay, J.-F. Soulier
MEA J.-F. Soulier
TEL 0.4-m f/5.4 Ritchey-Chretien + CCD
NET UCAC-4
0073P         C2017 02 11.31602 18 10 11.73 -20 09 51.5          14.9 N      W96
0073P         C2017 02 11.33598 18 10 17.98 -20 10 01.0          14.9 N      W96
0073P         C2017 02 11.35833 18 10 24.85 -20 10 12.5          15.1 N      W96
0073P         C2017 02 11.38876 18 10 34.29 -20 10 28.1          14.8 N      W96
0073Pa        C2017 02 11.31602 18 10 09.59 -20 09 35.0          13.3 N      W96
0073Pa        C2017 02 11.33598 18 10 15.77 -20 09 44.9          13.3 N      W96
0073Pa        C2017 02 11.35833 18 10 22.64 -20 09 56.2          13.2 N      W96
0073Pa        C2017 02 11.38876 18 10 32.04 -20 10 11.6          13.1 N      W96
----- end -----
NET UCAC-4
0073Pa        C2017 02 11.32351 18 10 11.85 -20 09 38.6          12.6 T      W96
0073Pa        C2017 02 11.35439 18 10 21.37 -20 09 54.1          12.6 T      W96
----- end -----

Pictures :
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image73PSchwassmannWachmannChile.htm

Congratulations Thierry !!

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François

  Images thanks to Andre Debackere and Las Cumbres Obs.

We look to have the early stage of an outburst.

Well done Thierrry Noel!
Please monitor this new outburst.

Richard Miles
BAA

From: "Maik Meyer maik@comethunter.de [comets-ml]"

To:
Sent: Friday, February 10, 2017 6:40 PM
Subject: Re: [comets-ml] 73P fragmentation

> Rob, all,
>
>> of this object. Therefore I’d say the odds are good that it’s part of
>> 73P. The only
>> factor that
>> argues against this conclusion is that the brighter object does not have
>> a tail that
>> I can see.
>
> it may be that the brighter and "stellar" object is in an early outburst
> phase and
> will become diffuse soon and spread fresh material later.
>
> 73P is prone to fragmentation so this is not astonishing.
>
> Maik

Date:  Mon, 13 Feb 2017 17:17:08 +0100
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  Image gallery of the German Comet Section
Hi,

I'm the maintainer of the image gallery of the German Comet Section.
I just want to tell you that we have almost reached the mark of 15.000
comet images/sketches/videos.

http://fg-kometen.vdsastro.de/bildere.htm

I invite every comet photographer/observer to upload
images/videos/sketches to the archive at

http://fg-kometen.vdsastro.de/pix/test/up2_e.php

If you need assistance, don't hesitate to contact me.

Please contact me if you want to upload old comet images.

--
Best regards,

Stefan Beck

"Astrophotography with small telescopes"
http://www.cometchaser.de

"Image processing for Comets"
http://www.cometchaser.de/imageprocessingcomets_v2.html

"Bildbearbeitung für Kometen"
http://www.cometchaser.de/imageprocessingcomets_de_v2.html

Date:  Thu, 16 Feb 2017 12:07:34 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann @ February 13,2017
Object/Date:
Comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann @ February 13,2017

Description:
Comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann imaged in February 13th, 2017. This periodic comet has being fragmenting en each apparition since 1995. In the approaching of this year only had being detected the fragment C until now, but in 10 February has been discovered other breakup: the new fragment named BT is observed in this image with high condensation and more bright than fragment-mother.

Tech data:
ASA 16" N 1420mm f/3,5 & Apogee Aspen CG16070 (L:1×120s Bin1 + RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Siding Spring

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/73p-schwassmann-wachmann-20170213/

Clear and Dark Skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Thu, 16 Feb 2017 16:02:42 +0000

Cirrus clouds

Date:  Thu, 16 Feb 2017 20:46:00 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 2P/Encke on Feb 16th.
Hi all,
Image of 2P/Encke low in the twilight on Feb 16th. Its dual tails are well seen.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/2p_encke_2017_02_16dp.jpg

4.1" F5. SBIG STL camera. LRGB. 12/1/1/1mins. Sun at -14.8.
Damian

Sent: Thursday, February 16, 2017 2:46 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet 2P/Encke on Feb 16th.

Hi all,

Image of 2P/Encke low in the twilight on Feb 16th. Its dual tails are well seen.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/2p_encke_2017_02_16dp.jpg

4.1" F5. SBIG STL camera. LRGB. 12/1/1/1mins. Sun at -14.8.

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro

Hi
all,
Image
of 2P/Encke low in the twilight on Feb 16th. Its dual tails
are well seen.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/2p_encke_2017_02_16dp.jpg

4.1"
F5. SBIG STL camera. LRGB. 12/1/1/1mins. Sun at
-14.8.

Date:  Fri, 17 Feb 2017 13:24:25 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann and its bt fragment: 16 Feb. 2017
Dear All,

last night we managed to capture this fragment remotely using the 16" robotic unit part of Tenagra Observatory in Arizona

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/02/17/comet-73pschwassmann-wachmann-bt-fragment-16-feb-2017/

All the best
Gianluca Masi

Date:  Fri, 17 Feb 2017 11:57:04 -0700
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann and its bt fragment: 16 Feb. 2017
Hi Bob, and all,

After a week and a half of cloudy weather  and, of course, the bright
moonlight, as well as the low altitude and the short viewing window  I¹ve
been able to observe, visually, component BT the past two mornings. The star
fields are crowded and confusing; yesterday, by the time I was able to
locate the correct field dawn was already underway, and while I did see
something clearly diffuse, the DSS field showed a pair of faint stars at
this same location. This morning, when I examined that same field, I could
see the pair of stars, but they were clearly stellar, and thus I did in fact
see the comet. Meanwhile, I was able to follow BT for about 15 minutes
(clear motion):

February 17.52 UT, m1=12.9, 0.8¹ coma, DC ~5 (41 cm reflector, 229x)

I could not convince myself I was seeing the primary component, although I
possibly was glimpsing ³something.² I observed it on a handful of occasions
during the previous dark run at m1 ~13.8, and that is probably beyond my
limit in the moonlight and low altitude.

Meanwhile, the next batch of clouds for the next storm has already moved in
. . .

Sincerely,
Alan 

Date:  Fri, 17 Feb 2017 18:59:37 +0000
From:  schmidtcamera250070@yahoo.com
Subject:  Encke feb 14-16
Dear Hisayoshi, Chris

Yes, this comet is a challenge. Zodiacal light and the bright Venus disturb. On feb 15th I had some stray light of Venus on parts of the chip. There is no scattered light at the observation station. But at the comet place the weakest visible stars were around 5m0.
On the images, it can be seen that the ion tail was slightly brighter on 15 February.

I feel, the dust trail is slightly weaker in the direction of the sun.

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=michael-jAcger-2P201702141516_1487357022.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=michael-jAcger-2P201702141516_1487357022.jpg

Best Regards
Michael Jäger 

Date:  Fri, 17 Feb 2017 22:48:02 +0000
From:  schmidtcamera250070@yahoo.com
Subject:  45P Feb. 15
Hello

Dark sky, comet 20° high
Feb. 15 UT 21.20 L-15x30sec no filter and 15x30 green
RGB 30/30/30sec 12"/4 G3-16200 3x3 bin

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=michael-jAcger-45P20170215ut2120_1487371418.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=michael-jAcger-45P20170215ut2120_1487371418.jpg

Best Regards
Michael Jäger

Date:  Sat, 18 Feb 2017 13:17:10 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann and its bt fragment: 16 Feb. 2017
Dear Bob,

thanks for appreciating it! Yes, I agree: it was a miracle to grab it that low
from the Northern hemisphere, this is where a very clear sky really helps.

All the best
Gianluca

Date:  Sat, 18 Feb 2017 14:16:05 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 45P Feb. 15
Michael,

Dark sky, comet 20°
highFeb. 15 UT 21.20 L-15x30sec no
filter and 15x30 greenRGB 30/30/30sec
12"/4 G3-16200 3x3 bin

Jäger 

Date:  Sat, 18 Feb 2017 16:42:08 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  comet 45P: 16 Feb 2017
Dear All,

last night Michael Schwartz and myself managed to capture this fragment
remotely using the 16" robotic unit part of Tenagra Observatory in Arizona:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/02/18/comet-45phonda-mrkos-pajdusakova-image-16-feb-2017/

All the best
Gianluca Masi 

Date:  Sat, 18 Feb 2017 17:49:00 +0000
From:  schmidtcamera250070@yahoo.com
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 45P Feb. 15
Chris

It is not so difficult to remove the stars.
But you can also leave them on the images.
This is even less effort.

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=michael-jAcger-45P20170215ut2117s14x35unfiltered_1487439659.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=michael-jAcger-45P20170215ut2117s14x35unfiltered_1487439659.jpg

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=michael-jAcger-45P20170215UT2057s15x35greemweb_1487439659.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=michael-jAcger-45P20170215UT2057s15x35greemweb_1487439659.jpg

I think most viewers tend to be the
Star-shaped images

Regards
Michael

Date:  Mon, 20 Feb 2017 17:12:05 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ February 19,2017
Object/Date:
Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ February 19,2017

Description:
Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova sails on the dark sky again, away from the Moon, rides the constellation Canes Venatici, at its right side the Whale Galaxy (NGC 4631) seems ascend in the field. A little more up float the Hockey Stick Galaxy (NGC 4656), an exotic irregular galaxy. The comet still shows a big coma with intense green color, at same time that deploys a dust tail toward west (downwards).

Tech data:
Takahashi FSQ-106ED 530mm f/5 & SBIG STL-11000M (L:3×120s Bin1+ RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Mayhill, New Mexico

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/45p-honda-mrkos-pajdusakova-20170219/

Clear and Dark Skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Mon, 20 Feb 2017 17:35:28 +0000
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ February 19,2017

Sent: Monday, 20 February 2017, 17:12
Subject: [Comet-Images] 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ February 19,2017

  Object/Date:Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ February 19,2017
Description:Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova sails on the dark sky again, away from the Moon, rides the constellation Canes Venatici, at its right side the Whale Galaxy (NGC 4631) seems ascend in the field. A little more up float the Hockey Stick Galaxy (NGC 4656), an exotic irregular galaxy. The comet still shows a big coma with intense green color, at same time that deploys a dust tail toward west (downwards).
Tech data:Takahashi FSQ-106ED 530mm f/5 & SBIG STL-11000M (L:3×120s Bin1+ RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Mayhill, New Mexico
Post and image link:http://cometografia.es/45p-honda-mrkos-pajdusakova-20170219/

Clear and Dark Skies.

José J. Chambó(Valencia, Spain)

font-weight:bold;}
#yiv0367291021

Object/Date:
Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ February
19,2017

Description:
Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova sails on the dark sky
again, away from the Moon, rides the constellation Canes
Venatici, at its right side the Whale Galaxy (NGC 4631)
seems ascend in the field. A little more up float the Hockey
Stick Galaxy (NGC 4656),
an exotic irregular galaxy. The comet still shows a big
coma with intense green color, at same time that deploys a
dust tail toward west (downwards).

Tech data:
Takahashi FSQ-106ED 530mm f/5 & SBIG STL-11000M
(L:3×120s Bin1+ RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Mayhill, New
Mexico

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/45p-honda-mrkos-pajdusakova-20170219/

Clear and Dark Skies.

José J.
Chambó
(Valencia,
Spain)

blog:
cometografia.es

twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 

Date:  Mon, 20 Feb 2017 19:42:45 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ February 19,2017

seems ascend in the field. A little more up float the Hockey

Subject: [Comet-Images] 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ February 19,2017

Object/Date:
Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova @ February 19,2017

Description:
Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova sails on the dark sky again, away from the Moon, rides the constellation Canes Venatici, at its right side the Whale Galaxy (NGC 4631) seems ascend in the field. A little more up float the Hockey Stick Galaxy (NGC 4656), an exotic irregular galaxy. The comet still shows a big coma with intense green color, at same time that deploys a dust tail toward west (downwards).

Tech data:
Takahashi FSQ-106ED 530mm f/5 & SBIG STL-11000M (L:3×120s Bin1+ RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Mayhill, New Mexico

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/45p-honda-mrkos-pajdusakova-20170219/

Clear and Dark Skies.

Date:  Tue, 21 Feb 2017 13:24:48 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  2P: 21 Feb. 2017
Hi all,

here it is an image of comet 2P captured by Gianluca Masi and Michael Schwartz:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/02/21/comet-2pencke-image-21-feb-2017/

Best
Gianluca

Date:  Thu, 23 Feb 2017 05:30:15 +0000
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet 73P-BT/Schwassmann–Wachmann Animation and Images - Feb 22, 2017
Hi All

Wide and narrowfield images and an animation when only 3.5 degrees away from the moon .
Taken from Warrumbungle Observatory near Siding Spring, Australia

Animation: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33064019405/
Positive narrowfield: www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33022294966/
Negative narrowfield: www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33022294056/
Positive widefield: www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33022316206/
Negative widefield: www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33022315286/
Positive narrowfield stacked: www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33022295046/
Negative narrowfield stacked. www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33022294056/

Clear Still Skies
Joe

From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2017-02-22 C2014B1 41P 45P
Hello everyone

3 comets observed yesterday evening, CLR filter

C/2014 B1 Schwartz (unfortunately with a collimation problem visible on
brightest stars)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2014B1_Schwarz.html

41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak (collimation corrected :) )
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/41P_Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak.html

45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/45P_Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova.html

Best
Luc

Date:  Fri, 03 Mar 2017 14:35:58 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak  3/1/17
Greetings all,

A brief soaking wet clear evening, and the 10" f/3.9 astrograph was pressed into service once again on this jewel of a comet. This image is just over an hour of integration time, and JUST starts to show a short stubby set of tail rays present to the lower left of the coma. Hopefully the tail will continue to develop!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Comet41P-030117.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Fri, 03 Mar 2017 16:17:52 +0100
From:  rolando ligustri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak  3/1/17
beautiful!

-----Messaggio originale-----
From: Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]
Sent: Friday, March 03, 2017 3:35 PM
To: Comet Group
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak 3/1/17

Greetings all,

A brief soaking wet clear evening, and the 10" f/3.9 astrograph was pressed into service
once again on this jewel of a comet. This image is just over an hour of integration time,
and JUST starts to show a short stubby set of tail rays present to the lower left of the
coma. Hopefully the tail will continue to develop!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Comet41P-030117.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Sat, 04 Mar 2017 11:58:57 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Comets 41P and 45P
Nearly simultaneous images for Comets 41P and 45P at prime focus via the ASO
astrograph showing the considerable difference in overall morphology of these two
bright comets. Arkansas Sky Observatories website/Alerts:
http://arksky.org/calendar/alerts/757-comets-41p-and-45p

------------
Dr. Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
WEB: www.arksky.org/
FACEBOOK: https://www.facebook.com/groups/421163751426836/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971

Date:  Mon, 06 Mar 2017 12:50:56 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak (Feb.25,2017)
Object/Date:
Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak @ Feb.25,2017 19:48 UT

Description:
Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak imaged on February 25th 2017 shows a coma with a diameter of 7 arcminutes and green-bluish color. At the moment of taking this image the comet had a brightness around magnitude 10.
Tech data:
GSO 8" f/3.8 & Canon EOS-100D (4 x 240 sec. at ISO-1600) from Hoya Redonda, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/41p-tuttle-giacobini-kresak-20170225/

Clear and Dark Skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo

18h 48m UT; RA 19 30 51.07 Dec -10 09 09.5

Date:  Mon, 13 Mar 2017 19:46:20 +0100
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] image 73P  13/03
Hello Chris,

The pixelresolution is 1.36” and the distance between the 2 fragments is about 8”, it is just about 5 … 6 pixels distance from the both centers, It ‘looks’ that they are ‘merge’ but this is only from our side of view J

Clear skies,

erik

Date:  Thu, 16 Mar 2017 12:22:33 +0000
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet C/2017 E4 Lovejoy Images and Animation - March 14, 2017
Taken from New Mexico Skies Observatory using an SBIG STXL-6303 camera and Planewave CDK 43 cm telescope on a Software Bisque PME 2 Mount
5 x 2 min exposure; clear filter; 12h 13m UT

LINK
Animation: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33085654900/
Single shot positive: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33469178275/
Single shot negative: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33313060142/
Stack on comet positive: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33469174885/
Stack ln comet negative: https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33469176715/

Clear, still skies
Joe

Joseph Brimacombe

Date:  Mon, 20 Mar 2017 20:05:10 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2015 V2 Johnson (Mar.1,2017)
Object/Date:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) @ March 1,2017 11:03 UT

Description:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) imaged on March 1st 2017, although continues showing a similar morphology, since my last image taken a month ago it shows now a brightness and size increase, dust tail slightly more curved and gassy coma now with a intense green color.

Tech data:
Planewave 17" CDK 1940mm f/4.5 & FLI-PL6303E (L:4×300s Bin1+ RGB:1x120s Bin2) from Mayhill, New Mexico

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2015v2-johnson-20170301/

Clear and Dark Skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo

Date:  Wed, 22 Mar 2017 04:28:20 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 45P - 3/19/17 - Phantom of a bright comet
Hi all,

This comet has now become so faint and diffuse, that it is at least 10x or more fainter than imaging the Horse head nebula. I gave it a total of 2 hours of exposure with the 10 inch and it was barely there. It is within a horde of faint galaxies in Leo, down to 19th magnitude here in this shot. Could this be the last shot of this comet I ever try?

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Comet45P-031917.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Wed, 22 Mar 2017 08:41:26 +0000
From:  1rondee@gmail.com
Subject:  Re: Comet 45P - 3/19/17 - Phantom of a bright comet
No, keep going, that's a very nice image of a very dim Comet.

Ron
Date:  Wed, 22 Mar 2017 11:10:22 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  41P, Messier 97 and Messier 108: 22 Mar. 2017
Dear All,

This capture is from a few minutes ago. Michael Schwartz and myself managed to
capture this meeting remotely using the 16" robotic unit part of Tenagra
Observatories in Arizona:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/03/22/comet-41ptuttle-giacobini-kresak-meets-messier-97-messier-108-22-mar-2017/

All the best
Gianluca Masi

> A: "Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com",
> Ogg: [Comet-Images] 41P, Messier 97 and Messier 108: 22 Mar. 2017
>
> Dear All,
>
> This capture is from a few minutes ago. Michael Schwartz and myself managed to
> capture this meeting remotely using the 16" robotic unit part of Tenagra
> Observatories in Arizona:
>
> http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/03/22/comet-41ptuttle-giacobini-kresak-meets-messier-97-messier-108-22-mar-2017/
>
> All the best
> Gianluca Masi
>

Date:  Sat, 25 Mar 2017 16:13:11 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak  3/24/17 - Inside Big Dipper

Just from last night, here is a long exposure of the beautiful round green comet splashing its way through the bowl of the Big Dipper. Few comets have actually gone inside the bowl of this asterism, and this is a classic image. The focal length here was carefully chosen at 50mm to get the exact composition I wanted, four bowl stars and one handle star. Rotation is along N-S lines of course, and the images orientation allows the viewer to instantly recognise the bowl shape.

Photo Details:

50mm f/4.5 Sigma Lens
Canon XTi at ISO 800
1h 45m total exposure time
from Payson,Az on 3/24/17

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/xtiastro/Comet41P-032417dippper.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Sat, 25 Mar 2017 13:53:51 -0500
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak 3/24/17 - Inside Big Dipper
What a great image, Chris. Congratulations!
Bob

Date:  Sun, 26 Mar 2017 00:37:13 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak  (Mar.18,2017)
Object/Date:
Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak @ Mar.18,2017 21:53 UT

Description:
Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak imaged in March 18th 2017, shows a sharpen central condensation around wich extends a fuzzy coma with a diameter at least 12 arcminutes wide. Toward southeast (to down-left) is perceived the trace of a faint and short ionic tail.

Tech data:
GSO 8" f/4.0 & Atik 383L+ (L:3×120s Bin1) from Vallés, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/41p-tuttle-giacobini-kresak-20170318/

Clear and Dark Skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Sun, 26 Mar 2017 02:40:11 +0000

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Object/Date:
Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak  @ Mar.18,2017 21:53
UT

Description:
Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak imaged in March 18th
2017, shows a sharpen central condensation around wich
extends a fuzzy coma with a diameter at least 12 arcminutes
wide. Toward southeast (to down-left) is perceived the trace
of a faint and short
ionic tail.

Tech data:
GSO 8" f/4.0 & Atik 383L+ (L:3×120s Bin1)
from Vallés, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/41p-tuttle-giacobini-kresak-20170318/

Clear and Dark Skies.

José J.
Chambó
(Valencia,
Spain)

cometografia.es

Date:  Sun, 26 Mar 2017 02:43:11 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak  3/24/17 -with 10 inch f/3.9
HI all,

This was taken last night with choppy seeing, and compliments my wide angle shot posted earlier today. The comets coma is really quite extended, and hard stretches its green glow fills the one degree field.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Comet41P-032417.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

From: Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]
Sent: Saturday, March 25, 2017 5:13 PM
To: Comet Group
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak 3/24/17 - Inside Big Dipper

Just from last night, here is a long exposure of the beautiful round green comet splashing
its way through the bowl of the Big Dipper. Few comets have actually gone inside the bowl
of this asterism, and this is a classic image. The focal length here was carefully chosen
at 50mm to get the exact composition I wanted, four bowl stars and one handle star.
Rotation is along N-S lines of course, and the images orientation allows the viewer to
instantly recognise the bowl shape.

Photo Details:

50mm f/4.5 Sigma Lens
Canon XTi at ISO 800
1h 45m total exposure time
from Payson,Az on 3/24/17

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/xtiastro/Comet41P-032417dippper.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

From:  Gianluca Masi

16" robotic unit part of Tenagra Observatories in Arizona:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/03/26/comet-315ploneos-image-25-mar-2017/

All the best
Gianluca Masi

https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/33256261910 https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/33256261910

though tail was clearer and longer on this enhanced dirty frame.

https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/33524344991 https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/33524344991

It comes near the earth on April 1, 2017.

I will drive or fly for dark and clear sky at the night.

Best Wishes,

hiro 

Date:  Sun, 26 Mar 2017 19:52:00 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann GMAIL 
Subject:  2P Encke

conditions in Nambia and I think he was right with his advice:

/375_2P_25_03.jpg

/376_2P_26_03.jpg

best regards and many thanks again to Michael

Gerald

{margin-right:0cm;margin-left:0cm;font-size:12.0pt;}

{}

Date:  Sat, 01 Apr 2017 18:14:44 +0200
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] images comet 73P
Hi Chris,

I'm not sure about that, i see a hint of the secundary fragment (with increasing the zoomfactor in astrometrica), but the distance is now about 1/3 arc.sec. The resolution of the optical setup is 1.4 arc.sec. resolution isn't small enough to get e clear separation of the 2 parts. Maybe within a few days , when the two parts are further apart, we can observe it better.

clear skies

Erik

Van: "Comet-Images"
Aan: "Comet-Images"
Verzonden: Zaterdag 1 april 2017 17:09:12
Onderwerp: Re: [Comet-Images] images comet 73P

Erik, it looks like that secondary fragment disappeared?

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Date:  Sun, 02 Apr 2017 23:10:19 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak  4/2/17 - with "Cometracker"
HI all,

The moon is getting bigger every night, so one last stab at trying to get some sort of faint gas tail on this object, which is closest to earth now. No big tail, but a spike coming out of the coma pointing down here.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Comet41P-032417.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Dear All,

I'm pleased to share this new pic of comet C/2017 E4 Lovejoy, captured this morning:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/04/03/comet-c2017-e4-lovejoy-outstanding-image-02-apr-2017/

Gianluca

Date:  Tue, 04 Apr 2017 03:45:39 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Johnson V2 - 4/2/17 Yesterday morning
HI all,

This is a deep 2 hour total integration time with the 10 inch astrograph, and you can see the comet is getting significantly larger with each passing month. There are many dim galaxies in the background in this field, despite the fact that we are in Hercules and getting near the zone of avoidance in the Milky Way. At 9th magnitude, it was rather un inspiring visually, however it is a fine target for deep large aperture shots!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CometJohnson040217.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Tue, 04 Apr 2017 06:11:08 +0200
From:  rolando ligustri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Johnson V2 - 4/2/17 Yesterday morning
bella! :)

regards
ROlando

-----Messaggio originale-----
From: Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]
Sent: Tuesday, April 04, 2017 5:45 AM
To: Comet Group ; Comet Mailing List
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Johnson V2 - 4/2/17 Yesterday morning

HI all,

This is a deep 2 hour total integration time with the 10 inch astrograph, and you can see
the comet is getting significantly larger with each passing month. There are many dim
galaxies in the background in this field, despite the fact that we are in Hercules and
getting near the zone of avoidance in the Milky Way. At 9th magnitude, it was rather un
inspiring visually, however it is a fine target for deep large aperture shots!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CometJohnson040217.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Posted by: Chris Schur

Date:  Wed, 05 Apr 2017 06:34:47 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2015 ER61 PANSTARRS in outburst (Apr.1-4,2017)

Object/Date:
Comet C/2015 ER61 (PNASTARRS) @ April 1,2017 18:31 UT / April 1,2017 18:42 UT

Description:
Outburst in C/2015 ER61 (PANSTARRS), I think is several magnitudes brighter, and with a ionic tail showing structural details. The images wasn’t processed, only stretched at same intensity, these are two images of 120 seconds with same equipment.

Tech data (both):
Planewave 20″ CDK 2259mm f/4.4 & FLI-PL09000 (L:1×120s Bin1), from Siding Spring, (Australia)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2015er61-panstarrs-20170404/

Clear and Dark Skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo

An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com

Stunning image Gerald - the tail near the head has a distinctive "scalloped" appearance not seen often.

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Comet C/2017 E4 image: 07 April 2017

Dear All,

I'm pleased to share this new pic of comet C/2017 E4 Lovejoy, captured this morning:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/04/07/comet-c2017-e4-lovejoy-image-07-apr-2017/

It was taken by Gianluca Masi and Michael Schwartz, as part of a cooperation between Tenagra Observatories, Ltd., in Arizona and the Virtual Telescope Project in Italy.

Clear skies
Gianluca

From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Comet 41P and NGC 6015: 09 April 2017
Dear All,

I'm pleased to share this new pic of comet 41P "meeting" galaxy NGC 6015, captured this morning, despite the extremely bright Moon:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/04/09/comet-41ptuttle-giacobini-kresak-meets-galaxy-ngc-6015-image-09-apr-2017/

It was taken by Gianluca Masi and Michael Schwartz, as part of a cooperation between Tenagra Observatories, Ltd., in Arizona and the Virtual Telescope Project in Italy.

Date:  Mon, 10 Apr 2017 06:02:52 +0000
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  41P, C2015V2, C2017E4 and C 2015ER61 ...
Good morning.
Observation of the 4 brightest comets between 201704.02 and 04.10, with the T300 France :

=> 41P Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak
Images with Filter Clear and Red J/C, G.R. : 20°.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image41PTuttleGiacobiniKresakfrance.htm

=> C 2015 V2 Johnson
Images with Filter Clear and Red J/C.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2015V2Johnsonfrance.htm

=> C 2017 E4 Lovejoy
Images with Filter Clear and Red J/C, G.R. : 20°, animations.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2017E4Lovejoyfrance.htm

=> C 2015 ER61 Panstarrs
Images with Filter Clear 1X1 and 2X2.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2015ER61Panstarrsfrance.htm

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François

Date:  Fri, 14 Apr 2017 16:06:34 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak  4/13/17 last night
HI all,

Clear but dusty skies from the high winds have returned to Arizona and last night we had the opportunity for about an hour before the moon rose to get in a shot of this comet. The comet is showing a greenish extension in the coma, like a large cloud following the head off to one side. Very nice to finally see a hint of tail on this bright object!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Comet41p-041317.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Fri, 14 Apr 2017 19:28:52 +0200
From:  rolando ligustri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak 4/13/17 last night
bella!

:)

Rolando

-----Messaggio originale-----
From: Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]
Sent: Friday, April 14, 2017 6:06 PM
To: Comet Group
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacombini-Kresak 4/13/17 last night

HI all,

Clear but dusty skies from the high winds have returned to Arizona and last night we had
the opportunity for about an hour before the moon rose to get in a shot of this comet.
The comet is showing a greenish extension in the coma, like a large cloud following the
head off to one side. Very nice to finally see a hint of tail on this bright object!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Comet41p-041317.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Posted by: Chris Schur

Date:  Sun, 16 Apr 2017 22:42:59 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak (Mar.22,2017)
Object/Date:
Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak @ 22-Mar-2017 23:45 UT

Description:
Comet 41P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova imaged in March 22th 2017 when was inside of the Big Dipper. The tablespoon also contained the Owl Nebula (M 97) at right, and the galaxy M 108 at upper. The comet, in down left, shone at magnitude 8 and had a coma with a diameter of 15 arcminutes wich contains a short tail toward south (right).

Tech data:
GSO 8" f/3.8 & Canon EOS-100D (3 x 120 sec. at ISO-1600) from Vallés, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/41p-tuttle-giacobini-kresak-20170322/

Clear and Dark Skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo

Date:  Wed, 19 Apr 2017 23:14:14 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak (Mar.25,2017)
Object/Date:

Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak @ Mar.25,2017 02:25 UT

Description:
Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak imaged on March 25th 2017, five days before its maximum approaching to Earth at a distance of 0.14 AU. The greenish and very diffuse coma had extended until a diameter of 20 arcminutes, shining around magnitude 7.5.

Tech data:
GSO 8" f/4.0 & Atik 383L+ (L:3×90s Bin1 + RGB:1x30s Bin2) from Vallés, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/41p-tuttle-giacobini-kresak-20170325/

Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Thu, 20 Apr 2017 17:08:30 +0200

/403_73P_03_04.jpg

Date:  Thu, 20 Apr 2017 20:53:55 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2017 E4 (Lovejoy) on April 5th.
Hi all,Data for this has been sat on my computer for the past two weeks and only now had time to process it. Remarkable that it is now disintegrating just a couple of weeks later.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2017e4_2017_04_05dp.jpg
I opted to stack many short exposures (60s) to preserve the delicate tail streamers which are otherwise lost.
Best Wishes
Damian

now had time to process it. Remarkable that it is now disintegrating just a

streamers which are otherwise lost.

Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

Date:  Fri, 21 Apr 2017 16:46:36 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Johnson V2 - 4/20/17 Last night
Hi all,

This comet is turning into an excellent imaging target, now bright at 7th magnitude and high in the sky around 10pm and later. Here is a 36 minute integration set on this stunning object, and I hope you can get out to image or view this celestial showpiece!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/JohnsonV2-042017.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Sat, 22 Apr 2017 00:00:23 +0200
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  Encounter of asteroid 2014 JO25 with Earth on April,19 2017
Hi,

here you find links to my observation of the encounter with Apollo Asteroid 2014 JO25 on April, 19 2017 from my new location
Dettelbach:

http://www.b82maidbronn.de/mp4/2014jo25_xxx/2014jo25_20170419.mp4

http://www.b82maidbronn.de/mp4/2014jo25_xxx/2014jo25_20170419.html

Note the size of the videos, please: 49 MB.

The total observation time was 1h25'.

The asteroid was something brighter as expected with about 10.5 mag.

Although I abandoned a visual observation in favor of photography.

Clear skies

Bernhard Häusler

B82 Maidbronn

www.b82maidbronn.de 

Date:  Fri, 21 Apr 2017 23:53:29 +0000

Alfons,

Really like that Lovejoy shot - such a gorgeous tail! In the trees for me - thats what I get for living in a massive conifer forest. ;)

But 45P is the pale ghost of what it once was. Surprising its still so large.

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Date:  Sat, 22 Apr 2017 13:22:49 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  315P and Palomar 4
Dear All,

last night, I imaged comet 315P, remotely using the 17" robotic unit part of the
Virtual Telescope Project in Italy:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/04/22/comet-315ploneos-palomar-4-galaxy-21-apr-2017/

The extreme halo globular cluster Palomar 4 added to the scene.

All the best
Gianluca 

Date:  Sat, 22 Apr 2017 17:33:57 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi

remotely, using the 16" robotic unit part of Tenagra Observatories in Arizona:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/04/22/comet-c2017-e4-lovejoy-image-22-apr-2017/

All the best
Gianluca Masi

From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Fw: [comets-ml] C/2015V2 ion tail


----- Forwarded Message -----
From: "denis buczynski buczynski8166@btinternet.com [comets-ml]"
To: Comets-ml
Sent: Sunday, 23 April 2017, 17:39
Subject: [comets-ml] C/2015V2 ion tail

  Hello all, I was able to image comet C/2015 V2 last night from MPC Code I81. The image shows a strong ion tail feature in this image. Although this feature has been imaged previously the feature looks rather enhanced in this image.Image at :Comet /2015 V2 Johnson | British Astronomical Association

Date:  Mon, 24 Apr 2017 11:13:20 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2017 E4 Lovejoy: 23 Apr. 2017, perihelion
Dear All,

I'm pleased to share this image of comet C/2017 E4 Lovejoy, imaged yesterday morning, the day of its perihelion. The object was only 6 deg. above the NE horizon. The head of the comet shows a condensation.

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/04/24/comet-c2017-e4-lovejoy-image-perihelion-date-23-apr-2017/

The image was taken by Gianluca Masi and Michael Schwartz, as part of a cooperation between Tenagra Observatories, Ltd., in Arizona and the Virtual Telescope Project in Italy.

Clear skies
Gianluca 
Date:  Mon, 24 Apr 2017 11:11:53 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2015 V2 Johnson (Mar.26,2017)
Object/Date:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) @ Mar.26,2017 03:08 UT

Description:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) imaged in March 26th 207, at that time with a brightness of magnitude 9.5 shows in this image a greenish coma with a diameter of 10 arcminutes and a dust tail near 20 arcminutes toward northwest.

Tech data:
GSO 8" f/3.7 & Atik 383L+ (L:12×300s Bin1 + RGB:3x120s Bin2) from Vallés, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2015v2-johnson-20170326/

Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Mon, 24 Apr 2017 15:36:58 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2017 E4 Lovejoy: 24 Apr. 2017
Dear All,

I'm pleased to share this new image of comet C/2017 E4 Lovejoy, imaged a few hours ago. The comet was very low above the horizon.

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/04/24/comet-c2017-e4-lovejoy-image-perihelion-date-23-apr-2017/

The image was taken by Gianluca Masi and Michael Schwartz, as part of a cooperation between Tenagra Observatories, Ltd., in Arizona and the Virtual Telescope Project in Italy.

Clear skies
Gianluca

Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet C/2017 E4 (Lovejoy) on April 7th.

is an image of the comet from back on April 7th. Nice tail

Date:  Sat, 29 Apr 2017 11:28:23 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2017 E4 Lovejoy (Mar.30, 2017)
A belated image...

Object/Date:
Comet C/2017 E4 (Lovejoy) @ March 30,2017 11:26 UT

Description:
Comet C/2017 E4 (Lovejoy) imaged in March 31, 2017 only twenty days after its discovery and during maximum approach to Earth to 0.6 AU. In outburst and increasing its brightness from magnitude 15 when was discovered by Terry Lovejoy until magnitude 7 at time I took this image. The comet thrown then a ionic tail more than 1 degree long, going out of the field toward west (upwards). Showing a greenish coma of a diameter of 8 arcminutes so flattened shape, a trace of possible disintegration during next approching to Sun, such as succeded only ten days subsequently of take this image.

Tech data:
Planewave 17" CDK 1940mm f/4.5 & FLI-PL6303E (L:3×60s Bin1 + RGB:1x30s Bin2) from Mayhill, New Mexico

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2017e4-lovejoy-20170330/



Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo

2014 JO25

Date:  Sun, 30 Apr 2017 16:03:46 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2017 E4: 30 Apr. 2017
Dear All,

here it is an image of this comet which Michael Schwartz and myself managed to
capture this morning ago, remotely using the 16" robotic unit part of Tenagra
Observatories in Arizona.

Observing conditions were extreme, but we could document the present status of
the comet.

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/04/30/comet-c2017-e4-lovejoy-extreme-image-30-apr-2017/

All the best
Gianluca Masi

Date:  Sun, 30 Apr 2017 22:34:21 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 45P - 4/29/17
Hi all,

I said last time I shot this object a month ago it would be the last time ever, since it was so terribly faint. So what did I do last night? Shot the comet again! Oh man, its so terribly faint - even a 5 minute sub I could just barely make it out from the noise. This would be a great project for someone with one of those robotic mounts to have the mount follow the motion of the comet in each sub frame. Anyway, this is REALLY my last shot of this comet for a long time! ;)

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Comet45P-042917.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Mon, 01 May 2017 01:11:33 +0000

Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet 45P with NGC 3346 (May 1st.)

Hi all,

A very faded 45P passing across the small but very picturesque spiral galaxy
NGC 3346 in Leo.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/45p_2017_05_01dp.jpg

20"CDK. LRGB. 60mins total.

Best Wishes

Damian

71P taken on April 20th. 21st. and 29th.

Date:  Sat, 06 May 2017 21:11:46 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Nearby Red Dwarfs (May 2nd.)
Hi all,
Here are three of the nearest stars to Earth all captured on the same night. I specifically stuck to straight RGB to render the star colours well. All three of these red dwarfs have much the same deep orange colour. Wolf 359 is located in an especially barren field so really stands out. Its interesting how far all three have moved compared to the reference DSS images, especially Barnard's Star.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/redwarfs_2017_05_02dp.jpg

Best Wishes
Damian
 *************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

*****

My web server (www.astronomie.be) is still described as unsafe in
some web browsers (Firefox, etc.. )
But this has been resolved and can be safely visited again!
He is still on the blacklist see: 'Reported Attack Page!'

Sorry for these inconveniences!
Alfons

    41P Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak - false
color

    71P Clark

    315P LONEOS

    C2013 V4 Catalina

    C2014 OE4 PANSTARRS

    C2016 A1 PANSTARRS

    C2016 M1 PANSTARRS

    C2016 N6 PANSTARRS

    C2015 V2 Johnson

    C2015 V2 Johnson - false color

    C2015 V2 Johnson - Larson-Sekanina
filter

with a direct link to the image:

http://www.astronomie.be/alfons.diepvens/cometimages/index.html

Alfons Diepvens

Virus-free. www.avg.com

Date:  Sun, 14 May 2017 18:42:37 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Johnson V2 - 5/13/17   One Hour of Darkness.
Hi all,

with one hour between the end of astronomical twilight and moon rise, I squeezed in this image last night. The comet is nice and easy in the finder, and moving pretty fast at this point. Thanks for looking:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CometJohnsonV2051317.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Mon, 15 May 2017 14:45:52 +0000
From:  jbrimaco@bigpond.net.au
Subject:  Comet C/2015 V2 Johnson Near Alkalurops in Bootes Widefield L - May 14, 2017
Taken from New Mexico Skies Observatory using an SBIG STXL-11000 camera and Takahashi FSQ 106 telescope on a Software Bisque PME 2 Mount with AOX guiding.
1 x 30 min exposure; 04h 44m UT

LINK:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/33832913614/

Date:  Tue, 16 May 2017 08:00:32 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2015 ER61 PANSTARRS (Apr.4, 2017)
A delayed image...

Object/Date:
Comet C/2015 ER61 (PANSTARRS) @ April 4,2017 18:40 UT

Description:
Comet C/2015 ER61 (PANSTARRS) imaged in April 4th 2017, just after have an outburst wich did increase its brightness two magnitudes in oly some hours, passing from magnitude 8 to 6 and developing a long ionic tail with several trails going out of field toward west (to right).

Tech data:
Planewave 20" CDK 2259mm f/4.4 & FLI-PL09000 (L:3×120s Bin1 + RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Siding Spring, Australia

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2015-er61-panstarrs-20170404/




Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Tue, 16 May 2017 11:46:42 +0000

Taken from Savannah Skies Observatory using an SBIG STL-6303 camera and 41-cm RCOS telescope on a Software Bisque PME Mount.
20 x 30 sec; clear filter; 19h 31h UT

LINKS

Date:  Wed, 17 May 2017 16:21:48 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2015 ER61 (PanSTARRS) on April 4th
Hi all,
Here is an image of C/2015 ER61 on April4th. This was taken around the time an outburst in activity occurred. A nice delicate ion tail is present with several tail streamers.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2015er61_2017_04_04dp.jpg

16" F/3.5. LRGB 25mins total.

Date:  Thu, 18 May 2017 19:39:32 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2015 V2 may 17
Michael, that dust tail is getting closer to an anti tail. So I looked up the date of orbital plane crossing and its May 31st. Set your calendar!

Here is the source of my info:

https://in-the-sky.org/solarsystem.php?obj=ck15v020

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Fri, 19 May 2017 10:02:59 +0200
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] image comet C/2015 ER61 on 17 may 2017
Hello Michael,

Thanks for pointing me to this ‘feature’. This is a kind of artifact , I think by a possible cosmic ray that hit the CCD and was visible on only 1 of the ccd-images, check out the animated gif: http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/images/archive/C2015ER61_20170517_G39.gif

Meanwhile i correct the image and removed the artifact.

Thank you for drawing my attention to this

Kind regards,

Erik

Date:  Sun, 21 May 2017 18:21:50 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Johnson V2 - 5/20/17
Hi all,

It appears the daily appearance of the ion tail on this comet is quite variable! My luck is to shoot long on this one after the tail disappears for a few days. A deep hour long set on the comet last night with the wide field SV80 and CCD did not yield a significant gas tail, but the dust tail is sure pretty. I keep trying.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CometJohnson052017.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Sat, 27 May 2017 21:46:51 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Johnson V2 and its beautiful anti tail - 5/26/17
Hi all,

Now only four days from orbital plane crossing, the dust tail is morphing into a ray like structure, and the gas tail is pointing 180 degrees away - away from the Sun. It will be very interesting over the next few days to see if there are any changes to the dust tail.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CometJohnsonV2052617.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Fri, 02 Jun 2017 15:26:51 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Johnson V2 - last night 06/01/07
With blazing first quarter moon stealing the show! Well, I tried. we had clouds on May 31st, but last night was clear and I shot the short focus refractor for an hour in hopes of seeing more of the twin tails. The moon was not kind....

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CometJohnson060117.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Sat, 03 Jun 2017 14:38:14 +0200
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  Images of 41P, C/2015V2, C/2015O1, C/2016M1 and 71P
Hi,

I have updated my website with images of 41P, C/2015V2, C/2015O1,
C/2016M1 and 71P taken on May 26th. and 27th.

http://www.cometchaser.de/comets/41P.html
http://www.cometchaser.de/comets/2016M1.html
http://www.cometchaser.de/comets/2015O1.html
http://www.cometchaser.de/comets/71P.html
http://www.cometchaser.de/comets/2015V2.html

Off-topic:
On the main page are links to images of the SN 2017eaw in NGC6946, the
near earth flyby of 2017CS and of a Quasar.

Stefan Beck

Date:  Tue, 06 Jun 2017 09:28:17 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2015 V2 Johnson (Apr.5, 2017)
A delayed image...

Object/Date:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) @ April 5,2017 09:46 UT

Description:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) imaged on April 5th 2017, shows a greenish coma with a diameter 10 arcminutes wide and a dust tail extending about 20 arcminutes long toward northwest. The comet was shinning at that time with magnitude 9.

Tech data:
Planewave 20" CDK 2280mm f/4.5 & FLI-PL11002M (L:4×180s Bin1 + RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Mayhill, New Mexico

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2015-v2-johnson-20170405/




Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Tue, 06 Jun 2017 17:34:59 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2015 ER61 (PanSTARRS) on April 7th
Hi all,
A belated image of the comet from a few days after its outburst in April. Several tail streamers are present.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2015er61_2017_04_07dp.jpg

16"F3.5. LRGB 24mins total.
Best Wishes
Damian

Date:  Wed, 07 Jun 2017 08:51:03 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2015 ER61 PANSTARRS (Apr.29, 2017)
Image delayed.

Object/Date:
Comet C/2015 ER61 (PANSTARRS) @ April 29,2017 18:50 UT

Description:
Comet C/2015 ER61 (PANSTARRS) imaged on 29th April 2017, nearly a month after an outburst an after its approaching to Earth its brightness had dropped until 7.5 magnitude in this image taken 10 days before perihelion. In spite of this the comet keep showing a turquoise cocoon from wich departs a intense ionic tail that leaves the field toward southwest.

Tech data:
Planewave 20" CDK 2259mm f/4.4 & FLI-PL09000 (L:3×120s Bin1 + RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Siding Spring, Australia

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2015-er61-panstarrs-20170429/

Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 
Date:  Fri, 09 Jun 2017 12:23:00 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2015 V2 Johnson (May.2,2017)
Delayed.

Object/Date:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) @ May.2,2017 00:32 UT

Description:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) imaged on May 2nd 2017, aside from the tail of dust grains that remains to northwest, the comet has a ionic tail more narrower and fainter which departs from coma toward southwest (to bottom right), although is barely visible in this image. The bright red star is "2 Herculis" with 5.4 magnitude.

Tech data:
GSO 8" f/3.7 & Atik 383L+ (L:5×240s Bin1 + RGB:1x90s Bin2) from Vallés, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2015v2-johnson-20170502/

Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo

Date:  Sun, 11 Jun 2017 12:42:49 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak (May.2,2017)
Delayed:

Object/Date:
Comet 41P/Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak @ May.2,2017 01:19 UT

Description:
Comet 41P imaged on Mat 2nd 2017 three weeks after its perihelion, begun loss brightness, although in this image still shone around magnitude 7.5 showing a fuzzy coma with a diameter as 15 arcminutes wide around a sharp central condensation; also is visible a small tail as 8 arcminutes long toward southwest (to bottom right).

Tech data:
GSO 8" f/3.7 & Atik 383L+ (L:2×120s Bin1 + RGB:1x60s Bin2) from Vallés, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/41p-tuttle-giacobini-kresak-20170502/

Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo

C2015 V2 Johnson - Larson-Sekanina filter
C2015 VL62-Lemmon-Yeung-PANSTARRS
C2016 N4 MASTER

SN 2017 aew - SN in NGC 6946

with a direct link to the image:
http://www.astronomie.be/alfons.diepvens/cometimages/index.html

Alfons Diepvens

Date:  Thu, 15 Jun 2017 09:57:22 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2015 V2 Johnson (May 17, 2017)
Object/Date:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) @ May 17,2017 05:48 UT

Description:
A year and a half after be discovered by Jess Johnson through Catalina Sky Survey telescopes and after travel 750 million kilometers, the comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) approaches to inner of Solar Sistem these days, being observable by means of binoculars. While by astrophotography can be seen with much more detail, as in this widefield image in which can see its dust tail departing toward northwest (to bottom right) and its more faint ionic tail to south toward the brightest star Delta Bootis at left.

Tech data:
Takahashi FSQ-106ED f/5.0 & SBIG STL-11000M (L:3×300s Bin1 + RGB:1x120s Bin2) from Mayhill, New Mexico (USA)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2015v2-johnson-20170517/

Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo

C2016 M1 PANSTARRS
C2017 K2 PANSTARRS

with a direct link to the image:

Date:  Fri, 16 Jun 2017 22:59:08 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Johnson V2 - Last night  6/15/17
Hi all,

Comet Johnson V2 - Last night 6/15/17

Lots of fire smoke in our skies here in northern Arizona from wildfires on the Colorado Plateau. Despite a bit of obscuration, I was able to obtain this image last night before things got too bad. Getting the super faint gas tail to even show up in an image is a feat, I think this image is probably closer to art than science as far as processing goes. But there are some nice details to be had.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/CometJohnson061517.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Mon, 19 Jun 2017 02:41:17 +0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet 71p / Clark near Antares
HI all,

Comet 71p / Clark near Antares

With all the wild fires here in Arizona right now, the entire sky is not very transparent. Shooting low in the south is not the best right now! Here is a very short exposure of this comet I got a few nights ago before clouds rolled in and made a mess out of my sub frames. Still, a nice short stubby greenish tail and bright central condensation is visible:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Clark061517.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Tue, 20 Jun 2017 16:24:04 -0600
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  continuing . . .
Hello everyone,

Many of you may remember the ³Countdown to 500 Comets² I started a decade
ago, and finished some five years later, and then a brief follow-on
program. I stopped that, at least, I stopped making any public
announcements, due to a lot of issues going on in my personal life that were
just overwhelming me at the time (some of which I explore in my
auto-biography that came out two years ago). I¹ve continued observing
comets, of course, and I have made the occasional post (and participated in
the occasional debate) here from time to time, but a lot of my personal
efforts have been spent on trying to recover emotionally from everything
that happened and to re-establish some sense of ³normality² (whatever that
is). I think I¹m finally there, more or less, although I don¹t think I¹m
quite the same person that I was when this all started.

Anyway . . .

After giving this a lot of thought, I¹ve decided that I will once again go
public with the comets I add to that visual tally of mine. There is no
³program,² and I won¹t post any announcements or fanfare, but I¹ll make
posts to my web site as I add additional comets. I guess I have to call this
effort something, so I¹ve decided to call it ³Continuing With Comets.² I
plan to go live on the web site on July 1, and my intent at this time is to
keep this up indefinitely . . . until ³the end,² whatever ³the end² turns
out to be. Health issues, life circumstances, etc., etc., will obviously
play a role in this.

My reason for posting this now: I plan to have links to various comet image
galleries on my main ³Continuing² page. If you would like me to post a link
to your gallery, please let me know (preferably by private e-mail to avoid
taking up bandwidth). Also, I may occasional post images of some of the
comets I observe; most of these might be mine (since I have a DSLR camera
now), but I may want to post some of yours (duly credited, of course) from
time to time; please let me know (again, preferably via private e-mail) if
that is OK, if you would give blanket permission for that, or if you want me
to ask for permission for any specific image I might want to use.

Thanks to everyone for being a part of this with me.

Sincerely,
Alan

> 

Date:  Thu, 22 Jun 2017 10:24:01 +0000
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  C/2015 V2 Johnson (May 17, 2017)
Object/Date:
Comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) @ May.17,2017 22:44 UT

Description:
On same May 17th 2017, a few hours after get remotely my previous wide field picture, I took this more narrow image of the comet C/2015 V2 (Johnson) from my backyard with habitual equipment. Besides of the dust tail with certain redish dye toward bottom right corner, although very faint also can be seen the narrow ionic tail toward left and leaving the field.

Tech data:
GSO 8" f/3.7 & Atik 383L+ (L:4×300s Bin1 + RGB:1x120s Bin2) from Vallés, Valencia (Spain)

Post and image link:
http://cometografia.es/2015v2-johnson-20170517b/

Clear and dark skies.

________________________________
José J. Chambó
(Valencia, Spain)

blog: cometografia.es
twitter: @PepeChambo
facebook: facebook.com/JoseJChambo 

Date:  Thu, 22 Jun 2017 22:30:14 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2015 ER61 and its fragment "b": a new image (21 June 2017)
Dear All,

here it is a new image showing this fragment, recently announced via MPC:

https://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/06/22/comet-c2015-er61-b-new-image-21-june-2017/

The images used were obtained by Gianluca Masi and Michael Schwartz with the
robotic 16"-f/3.75 unit available at Tenagra Observatories, AZ.

best
Gianluca 

Date:  Sun, 25 Jun 2017 18:33:40 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2015 ER61 and its fragment "b": animation 3-21 June 2017
Dear All,

digging in our archives, we have found first evidence of fragment B on 2 June
2017, this providing some baseline to see the splitting event in evolution.

Here it is an animation using all the available images:

https://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/06/25/comet-c2015-er61-fragmentation-event-some-analysis/

The images used were obtained by Gianluca Masi and Michael Schwartz with the
robotic 16"-f/3.75 unit available at Tenagra Observatories, AZ.

best
Gianluca 

Date:  Thu, 06 Jul 2017 12:43:37 +0000

T400 RC SpaceObs Maury.A
